Press Start To Play: C#

Level 1: History

C# was made by Anders Hejlsberg, a software engineer at Microsoft in 2000. It was designed to be “a simple, modern, general-purpose, object-oriented programming language.” Around the time of its release, it was very similar to Java, but it has grown since then (the two languages still share quite a few similarities). As of now, it’s one of the most widely used coding languages; it consistently ranks within the top 10 most used.

It was made and released along with the .NET framework, which is software development framework tailored specifically for Windows based applications. It's part of the .NET platform, which is a cross platform way to run various applications. At its release, C# tools were associated with the release cycles of .NET libraries, but they no longer are linked as such. However, C# still is used very heavily in combination with the .NET framework and the .NET platform. You can learn more about it here!

An example of basic C# code is below: 

namespace HelloWorld
{
class Hello
{
    static void Main(string[] args)
    {
        System.Console.WriteLine("Hello World!");
    }
}
}

Level 2: C# vs C++ vs C

C is the oldest language of the trio; C# and C++ are variants of C. In fact, C++ was called “C with Classes” early in its development. C# is a bit further from C and holds more similarities with Java, which is another high level and object oriented language.

Here are some of the similarities and differences of the three languages:

C# C++ C
Paradigm Object oriented Object oriented Function driven
High or Low Level High level language - it has simple syntax and is very abstracted from machine code; it has automatic memory management by the garbage collector Low level language - it has some features of both high and low level languages, but has no automatic memory management Low level language - it can be used to directly access and alter memory, and it has no automatic memory management
Exception Handling Supported Supported Not supported
Security C# is much more secure than C++ and C and is not vulnerable to buffer overflow. You can look at how the .NET framework is built to stop various exploits before they happen here. It is vulnerable to buffer overflow due to having no automatic boundary checking. It is also vulnerable to format string attacks, and if the programmer doesn't check for certain inputs, outsiders can get data directly from the stack. There are encapsulation vulnerabilities, so outside people can alter C code through buffer overflow and other such exploits. You can learn more about this at Geeks for Geeks or you can take CS 240 at Wellesley!
Multiple Inheritance Not supported (though inheritance is supported) Supported (one class can extend multiple classes) Not supported (inheritance is not supported at all)
Compilation After compilation converts into intermediate language code After compilation converts directly into machine code After compilation converts directly into machine code
History Developed at Microsoft around 2000 as a more modern object oriented language Developed at Bell Labs around 1979 to try and add object oriented programming to C Developed at Bell Labs in the early 1970s for Unix operating systems
Main Uses Games, VR, web development, application development Games, VR, operating systems, embedded systems, databases, web browsers System software (like operating systems), embedded systems, libraries

Miniboss: What Wellesley classes use C#?

  • CS 121/MAS 121 - Introduction to Game Design
  • CS 221/MAS 221 - Digital Worlds for Gaming
  • CS 321/MAS 321 - Extended Reality

Level 3: Best IDEs

VS Code is by far one of the most used and most popular Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) to use with C#. It’s free and is one of the industry standards. It supports multiple platforms, works with Node.js, works with Git, and is highly customizable.

Microsoft Visual Studio is made by Microsoft, it therefore integrates extremely well with the .NET framework. It works with both macOS and Windows and comes with different workloads, which are specific bundles for different development targets (.NET desktop, .NET mobile, Universal Windows Platform, etc).

Level 4: What can you build with C#?

Games: All the scripting for the Unity Game Engine is done with C# and the Godot Game Engine also uses C#. Unity is one of the two industry standard Game Engines (along with Unreal Engine which uses C++) and Godot is also quite widely used (Godot is free and open-source; Unity and Unreal are free for hobbyist use).

Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) applications: Many VR and AR applications and experiences are also designed using the Unity Game Engine, which uses C#. A lot of AR application development is also done with C#.

Web services: Web services are easy to make with C# due to its integration with the .NET framework. You can take a look at Microsoft's guide on making a basic web service here.

Application development: Because the same code base can be used, C# can be used for cross platform development for Android, iOS, and Windows. It can also be used for both mobile and desktop applications.

Final Boss: Further Resources

For learning C# at any skill level, Geeks for Geeks has a comprehensive guide on over 200 topics ranging from syntax to control structures to the .NET framework.

W3Schools has a more hands on tutorial starting at the basics and moving from there. It also has examples of nice C# code, exercises to practice, and an online compiler!

For questions that aren't covered there, Stack Overflow can be a helpful resource to either pose questions yourself or see if others have had the same question as you (they probably have).

Unity's documentation has comprehensive details and examples for C# scripting for the Unity Game Engine. It has general and Unity specific information, which include explanations of prebuilt methods made by Unity.

For general guides as well as .NET guides, check out Microsoft's documentation.

Challenge complete!
Now onto the next world!

All the best,

Janavi Padala
